name: Automaton

datatypes.name: Automaton
datatypes.raw: data Automaton a b = Step (a -> (Automaton a b, b))

values.name: <<<
values.comment: Compose two automatons, chaining them together.
values.raw: (<<<) : Automaton b c -> Automaton a b -> Automaton a c

values.name: >>>
values.comment: Compose two automatons, chaining them together.
values.raw: (>>>) : Automaton a b -> Automaton b c -> Automaton a c

values.name: average
values.comment: Computes the running average of the last `n` inputs.

values.name: combine
values.comment:
Combine a list of automatons into a single automaton that produces a
list.

values.name: count
values.comment: Count the number of steps taken.

values.name: hiddenState
values.comment:
Create an automaton with hidden state. Requires an initial state and a
step function to step the state forward and produce an output.
values.raw: hiddenState : s -> (a -> s -> (s,b)) -> Automaton a b

values.name: pure
values.comment:
Create an automaton with no memory. It just applies the given function to
every input.

values.name: run
values.comment:
Run an automaton on a given signal. The automaton steps forward whenever the
input signal updates.
values.raw: run : Automaton a b -> b -> Signal a -> Signal b

values.name: state
values.comment:
Create an automaton with state. Requires an initial state and a step
function to step the state forward. For example, an automaton that counted
how many steps it has taken would look like this:

        count = Automaton a Int
        count = state 0 (\\_ c -> c+1)

It is a stateful automaton. The initial state is zero, and the step function
increments the state on every step.
values.raw: state : b -> (a -> b -> b) -> Automaton a b

values.name: step
values.comment: Step an automaton forward once with a given input.
values.raw: step : a -> Automaton a b -> (Automaton a b, b)

name: Basics

datatypes.name: Order
datatypes.comment:
Represents the relative ordering of two things.
The relations are less than, equal to, and greater than.
datatypes.raw: data Order = LT | EQ | GT

values.comment: The and operator. True if both inputs are True.
Function composition: `(f . g == (\\x -> f (g x)))`
Floating point division.

values.name: <|
values.comment:
Function application `f <| x == f x`. This function is useful for avoiding
parenthesis. Consider the following code to create a text element:

        text (monospace (toText "code"))

This can also be written as:

        text . monospace <| toText "code"
Exponentiation: `3^2 == 9`

values.name: abs
values.comment: Take the absolute value of a number.

values.name: atan
values.comment:
You probably do not want to use this. It takes `(y/x)` as the
argument, so there is no way to know whether the negative signs comes from
the `y` or `x`. Thus, the resulting angle is always between π/2 and -π/2
(in quadrants I and IV). You probably want to use `atan2` instead.

values.name: atan2
values.comment:
This helps you find the angle of a cartesian coordinate.
You will almost certainly want to use this instead of `atan`.
So `atan2 y x` computes *atan(y/x)* but also keeps track of which
quadrant the angle should really be in. The result will be between
π and -π, giving you the full range of angles.

values.name: ceiling
values.comment: Ceiling function, rounding up.

values.name: clamp
values.comment:
Clamps a number within a given range. With the expression
`clamp 100 200 x` the results are as follows:

      100     if x < 100
       x      if 100 <= x < 200
      200     if 200 <= x

values.name: compare
values.comment:
Compare any two comparable values. Comparable values include `String`, `Char`,
`Int`, `Float`, `Time`, or a list or tuple containing comparable values.
These are also the only values that work as `Dict` keys or `Set` members.

values.name: curry
values.comment:
Change how arguments are passed to a function.
This splits paired arguments into two separate arguments.

values.name: degrees
values.comment: Convert degrees to standard Elm angles (radians).

values.name: div
values.comment: Integer division, remainder is discarded.

values.name: e
values.comment: An approximation of e.

values.name: flip
values.comment: Flips the order of the first two arguments to a function.

values.name: floor
values.comment: Floor function, rounding down.

values.name: fromPolar
values.comment:
Start with polar coordinates (r,θ)
and get out cartesian coordinates (x,y).

values.name: fst
values.comment: Given a 2-tuple, returns the first value.

values.name: id
values.comment: Given a value, returns exactly the same value.

values.name: logBase
values.comment: Calculate the logarithm of a number with a given base: `logBase 10 100 == 2`

values.name: max
values.comment: Given two comparables, returns the larger one.

values.name: min
values.comment: Given two comparables, returns the smaller one.

values.name: mod
values.comment: Perform modular arithmetic: ``7 `mod` 2 == 1``

values.name: not
values.comment: Negate a boolean value: `(not True == False)` and `(not False == True)`

values.name: otherwise
values.comment: Equal to true. Useful as the last case of a multi-way-if.

values.name: pi
values.comment: An approximation of pi.

values.name: radians
values.comment: Convert radians to standard Elm angles (radians).

values.name: rem
values.comment: Finds the remainder after dividing one number by another: ``4 `rem` 3 == 1``

values.name: round
values.comment: Round a number to the nearest integer.

values.name: snd
values.comment: Given a 2-tuple, returns the second value.

values.name: sqrt
values.comment: Take the square root of a number.

values.name: toFloat
values.comment: Convert an integer into a float.

values.name: toPolar
values.comment:
Start with cartesian coordinates (x,y)
and get out polar coordinates (r,θ).

values.name: truncate
values.comment: Truncate a decimal number, rounding towards zero.

values.name: turns
values.comment:
Convert turns to standard Elm angles (radians).
One turn is equal to 360°.

values.name: uncurry
values.comment:
Change how arguments are passed to a function.
This combines two arguments into a sigle pair.

values.name: xor
values.comment: The exclusive-or operator. True if exactly one input is True.

values.name: |>
values.comment:
Forward function application `x |> f == f x`. This function is useful
for avoiding parenthesis and writing code in a more natural way.
Consider the following code to create a pentagon:

        scale 2 (move (10,10) (filled blue (ngon 5 30)))

This can also be written as:

        ngon 5 30 |> filled blue
                  |> move (10,10)
                  |> scale 2
The or operator. True if one or both inputs are True.

name: Char
document:
Functions for working with characters.

Like C, characters are enclosed in single quotes, and strings in double quotes.
Like Haskell, strings are just [lists](/docs/List.elm) of characters, so `"elm"
== ['e', 'l', 'm']`.

# Classification
@docs isUpper, isLower, isDigit, isOctDigit, isHexDigit

# Conversion
@docs toUpper, toLower, toLocaleUpper, toLocaleLower, toCode, fromCode

values.name: fromCode
values.comment: Convert from unicode.

values.name: isDigit
values.comment: True for ASCII digits `[0-9]`.

values.name: isHexDigit
values.comment: True for ASCII hexadecimal digits `[0-9a-fA-F]`.

values.name: isLower
values.comment: True for lower case letters.

values.name: isOctDigit
values.comment: True for ASCII octal digits `[0-7]`.

values.name: isUpper
values.comment: True for upper case letters.

values.name: toCode
values.comment:
Convert to unicode. Used with the [`Keyboard`](/docs/Keyboard.elm)
library, which expects the input to be uppercase.

values.name: toLocaleLower
values.comment: Convert to lower case, according to any locale-specific case mappings.

values.name: toLocaleUpper
values.comment: Convert to upper case, according to any locale-specific case mappings.

values.name: toLower
values.comment: Convert to lower case.

values.name: toUpper
values.comment: Convert to upper case.

name: Color
document:
Library for working with colors. Includes
[RGB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RGB_color_model) and
[HSV](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV) creation, gradients, and
built-in names.

# Creation
@docs rgb, rgba, hsv, hsva, grayscale, greyscale

# From Other Colors
@docs complement

# Gradients
@docs linear, radial

# Built-in Colors
These colors come from the [Tango
palette](http://tango.freedesktop.org/Tango_Icon_Theme_Guidelines)
which provides aesthetically reasonable defaults for colors. Each color also
comes with a light and dark version.

### Standard
@docs red, orange, yellow, green, blue, purple, brown

### Light
@docs lightRed, lightOrange, lightYellow, lightGreen, lightBlue, lightPurple,
    lightBrown

### Dark
@docs darkRed, darkOrange, darkYellow, darkGreen, darkBlue, darkPurple,
    darkBrown

### Eight Shades of Grey
These colors are a compatible series of shades of grey, fitting nicely
with the Tango palette.
@docs white, lightGrey, grey, darkGrey, lightCharcoal, charcoal, darkCharcoal, black

These are identical to the *grey* versions. It seems the spelling is regional, but
that has never helped me remember which one I should be writing.
@docs lightGray, gray, darkGray

datatypes.name: Color
datatypes.raw: data Color = Color Int Int Int Float

datatypes.name: Gradient
datatypes.raw:
data Gradient
  = Linear (Float,Float) (Float,Float) [(Float,Color)]
  | Radial (Float,Float) Float (Float,Float) Float [(Float,Color)]

values.name: complement
values.comment:
Produce a “complementary color”.
The two colors will accent each other.

values.name: grayscale
values.comment: Produce a gray based on the input. 0 is white, 1 is black.

values.name: hsv
values.comment:
Create [HSV colors](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV).  This is very
convenient for creating colors that cycle and shift.  Hue is an angle and should
be given in standard Elm angles (radians).

values.name: hsva
values.comment:
Create [HSV colors](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV)
with an alpha component for transparency.
values.raw: hsva : Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Color

values.name: linear
values.comment:
Create a linear gradient. Takes a start and end point and then a series of
“color stops” that indicate how to interpolate between the start and
end points. See [this example](/edit/examples/Elements/LinearGradient.elm) for a
more visual explanation.

values.name: radial
values.comment:
Create a radial gradient. First takes a start point and inner radius.  Then
takes an end point and outer radius. It then takes a series of “color
stops” that indicate how to interpolate between the inner and outer
circles. See [this example](/edit/examples/Elements/RadialGradient.elm) for a
more visual explanation.

values.name: rgb
values.comment: Create RGB colors from numbers between 0 and 255 inclusive.

values.name: rgba
values.comment:
Create RGB colors with an alpha component for transparency.
The alpha component is specified with numbers between 0 and 1.
values.raw: rgba : Int -> Int -> Int -> Float -> Color

name: Date

datatypes.name: Date
datatypes.raw: data Date = Date

datatypes.name: Day
datatypes.comment: Represents the days of the week.
datatypes.raw: data Day = Mon | Tue | Wed | Thu | Fri | Sat | Sun

datatypes.name: Month
datatypes.comment: Represents the month of the year.
datatypes.raw:
data Month = Jan | Feb | Mar | Apr
           | May | Jun | Jul | Aug
           | Sep | Oct | Nov | Dec

values.name: day
values.comment:
Extract the day of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `23`.

values.name: dayOfWeek
values.comment:
Extract the day of the week for a given date. Given the date 23 June
1990 at 11:45AM this returns the Day `Thu` as defined below.

values.name: hour
values.comment:
Extract the hour of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `11`.

values.name: minute
values.comment:
Extract the minute of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `45`.

values.name: month
values.comment:
Extract the month of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the Month `Jun` as defined below.

values.name: read
values.comment: Attempt to read a date from a string.

values.name: second
values.comment:
Extract the second of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `0`.

values.name: toTime
values.comment:
Convert a date into a time since midnight (UTC) of 1 January 1990 (i.e.
[UNIX time](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time)). Given the date 23 June
1990 at 11:45AM this returns the corresponding time.

values.name: year
values.comment:
Extract the year of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `1990`.

name: Dict

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key does not appear in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to the first dictionary.
values.raw: diff : Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty dictionary.

values.name: findWithDefault
values.comment:
Find the value associated with a key. If the key is not found,
return the default value.
values.raw: findWithDefault : v -> comparable -> Dict comparable v -> v

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from lowest
key to highest key.
values.raw: foldl : (comparable -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> Dict comparable v -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from highest
key to lowest key.
values.raw: foldr : (comparable -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> Dict comparable v -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a dictionary.

values.name: insert
values.comment:
Insert a key-value pair into a dictionary. Replaces value when there is
a collision.
values.raw: insert : comparable -> v -> Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key appears in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to values in the first dictionary.
values.raw: intersect : Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: keys
values.comment: Get all of the keys in a dictionary.

values.name: lookup
values.comment: Lookup the value associated with a key.
values.raw: lookup : comparable -> Dict comparable v -> Maybe v

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to all values in a dictionary.
values.raw: map : (a -> b) -> Dict comparable a -> Dict comparable b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a key is in a dictionary.
values.raw: member : comparable -> Dict comparable v -> Bool

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove a key-value pair from a dictionary. If the key is not found,
no changes are made.
values.raw: remove : comparable -> Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a dictionary with one key-value pair.
values.raw: singleton : comparable -> v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a dictionary into an association list of key-value pairs.

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two dictionaries. If there is a collision, preference is given
to the first dictionary.
values.raw: union : Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v -> Dict comparable v

values.name: values
values.comment: Get all of the values in a dictionary.

name: Either

datatypes.name: Either
datatypes.comment:
Represents any data may take two forms. For example, a user ID may be
either an `Int` or a `String`.

This can also be used for error handling `(Either String a)` where
error messages are stored on the left, and the correct values
(“right” values) are stored on the right.
datatypes.raw: data Either a b = Left a | Right b

values.name: consEither
values.comment:
If `Left`, add the value to the left list.
    If `Right`, add the value to the right list.

values.name: consLeft
values.comment:
If `Left`, add the value to the front of the list. 
    If `Right`, return the list unchanged

values.name: consRight
values.comment:
If `Right`, add the value to the front of the list.
    If `Left`, return the list unchanged.

values.name: either
values.comment:
Apply the first function to a `Left` and the second function to a `Right`.
    This allows the extraction of a value from an `Either`.
values.raw: either : (a -> c) -> (b -> c) -> Either a b -> c

values.name: isLeft
values.comment: True if the value is a `Left`.

values.name: isRight
values.comment: True if the value is a `Right`.

values.name: lefts
values.comment: Keep only the values held in `Left` values.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Split into two lists, lefts on the left and rights on the right. So we
    have the equivalence: `(partition es == (lefts es, rights es))`

values.name: rights
values.comment: Keep only the values held in `Right` values.

name: Http

aliases.name: Request

datatypes.name: Response
datatypes.comment:
The datatype for responses. Success contains only the returned message.
Failures contain both an error code and an error message.
datatypes.raw: data Response a = Success a | Waiting | Failure Int String

values.name: get
values.comment: Create a GET request to the given url.

values.name: post
values.comment: Create a POST request to the given url, carrying the given data.

values.name: request
values.comment:
Create a customized request. Arguments are request type (get, post, put,
delete, etc.), target url, data, and a list of additional headers.
values.raw: request : String -> String -> String -> [(String,String)] -> Request String

values.name: send
values.comment:
Performs an HTTP request with the given requests. Produces a signal
that carries the responses.

values.name: sendGet
values.comment:
Performs an HTTP GET request with the given urls. Produces a signal
that carries the responses.

name: JavaScript
document:
This library does basic conversions between Elm and JS values. This allows
the internal data structures of Elm to change and improve with no impact on JS
integration.

# Javascript to Elm
@docs toString, toInt, toFloat, toBool, toList

# JavaScript from Elm
@docs fromString, fromInt, fromFloat, fromBool fromList

datatypes.name: JSArray
datatypes.raw: data JSArray a = JSArray a

datatypes.name: JSBool
datatypes.raw: data JSBool = JSBool

datatypes.name: JSDomNode
datatypes.raw: data JSDomNode = JSDomNode

datatypes.name: JSNumber
datatypes.raw: data JSNumber = JSNumber

datatypes.name: JSObject
datatypes.raw: data JSObject = JSObject

datatypes.name: JSString
datatypes.raw: data JSString = JSString

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Produces a uniform JavaScript array with all members of the same type.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Requires that the input array be uniform (all members have the same type)

name: Json

datatypes.name: JsonValue
datatypes.comment:
This datatype can represent all valid values that can be held in a JSON
object. In Elm, a proper JSON object is represented as a (Dict String JsonValue)
which is a mapping from strings to Json Values.
datatypes.raw:
data JsonValue
    = String String
    | Number Float
    | Boolean Bool
    | Null
    | Array [JsonValue]
    | Object (Dict.Dict String JsonValue)

values.name: fromJSObject
values.comment: Convert a JS object into a `JsonValue`.

values.name: fromJSString
values.comment:
Parse a JavaScript string representation of a proper JSON object into
its Elm representation.

values.name: fromString
values.comment:
Parse a string representation of a proper JSON object into
its Elm representation.

values.name: toJSObject
values.comment:
Convert a `JsonValue` into a `JSObject`. Paired with the
[`JavaScript.Experimental` library](/docs/JavaScript/Experimental.elm),
This lets you convert strings into Elm records:

       import JavaScript.Experimental as JS

       stringToRecord str =
           case fromString str of
             Just jsonValue -> Just (JS.toRecord (toJSObject jsonValue))
             Nothing -> Nothing

values.name: toJSString
values.comment:
Convert a proper JSON object into a JavaScript string.
Note that the type JSString seen here is not the same as the type constructor
JsonString used elsewhere in this module.

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Convert a `JsonValue` into a prettified string.
The first argument is a separator token (e.g. \" \", \"\\n\", etc.) that will
be used for indentation in the prettified string version of the JSON.

name: Keyboard

aliases.name: KeyCode
aliases.comment:
Type alias to make it clearer what integers are supposed to represent
in this library. Use [`Char.toCode`](docs/Char.elm#toCode) and
[`Char.fromCode`](/docs/Char.elm#fromCode) to convert key codes to characters.
Use the uppercase character with `toCode`.

values.name: arrows
values.comment:
A signal of records indicating which arrow keys are pressed. `{ x = 0, y = 0 }` when pressing no arrows.
`{ x =-1, y = 0 }` when pressing the left arrow.
`{ x = 1, y = 1 }` when pressing the up and right arrows.
`{ x = 0, y =-1 }` when pressing the down, left, and right arrows.

values.name: ctrl
values.comment: Whether the control key is pressed.

values.name: directions
values.comment:
Custom key directions to support different locales. The order is up, down,
left, right.
values.raw: directions : KeyCode -> KeyCode -> KeyCode -> KeyCode -> Signal { x:Int, y:Int }

values.name: enter
values.comment: Whether the enter key is pressed.

values.name: isDown
values.comment: Whether an arbitrary key is pressed.

values.name: keysDown
values.comment: List of keys that are currently down.

values.name: lastPressed
values.comment: The latest key that has been pressed.

values.name: shift
values.comment: Whether the shift key is pressed.

values.name: space
values.comment: Whether the space key is pressed.

values.name: wasd
values.comment:
Just like the arrows signal, but this uses keys w, a, s, and d,
which are common controls for many computer games.

name: List

values.comment:
Puts two appendable things together:

      [1,1] ++ [2,3] == [1,1,2,3]
      "abc" ++ "123" == "abc123"
Add an element to the front of a list `(1 :: [2,3] == [1,2,3])`

values.name: all
values.comment: Check to see if all elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: and
values.comment: Check to see if all elements are True.

values.name: any
values.comment: Check to see if any elements satisfy the predicate.

values.name: concat
values.comment:
Concatenate a list of appendable things:

      concat ["tree","house"] == "treehouse"

values.name: concatMap
values.comment:
Map a given function onto a list and flatten the resulting lists.

      concatMap f xs == concat (map f xs)

values.name: drop
values.comment: Drop the first n members of a list: `(drop 2 [1,2,3,4] == [3,4])`

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Keep only elements that satisfy the predicate:
`(filter isLower "AaBbCc" == "abc")`

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Reduce a list from the left: `(foldl (::) [] "gateman" == "nametag")`

values.name: foldl1
values.comment: Reduce a list from the left without a base case. List must be non-empty.

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Reduce a list from the right: `(foldr (+) 0 [1,2,3] == 6)`

values.name: foldr1
values.comment: Reduce a list from the right without a base case. List must be non-empty.

values.name: head
values.comment:
Extract the first element of a list. List must be non-empty.
`(head [1,2,3] == 1)`

values.name: intersperse
values.comment:
Places the given value between all members of the given list.

      intersperse ' ' "INCEPTION" == "I N C E P T I O N"

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Check if a list is empty `(isEmpty [] == True)`

values.name: join
values.comment:
Places the given value between all of the lists in the second
argument and concatenates the result.

      join "a" ["H","w","ii","n"] == "Hawaiian"

values.name: last
values.comment:
Extract the last element of a list. List must be non-empty.
`(last [1,2,3] == 3)`

values.name: length
values.comment: Determine the length of a list: `(length "innumerable" == 11)`

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to every element of a list: `(map sqrt [1,4,9] == [1,2,3])`

values.name: maximum
values.comment: Find the maximum element in a non-empty list: `maximum [1,4,2] == 4`

values.name: minimum
values.comment: Find the minimum element in a non-empty list: `minimum [3,2,1] == 1`

values.name: or
values.comment: Check to see if any elements are True.

values.name: partition
values.comment: Split a list based on the predicate.

values.name: product
values.comment: Get the product of the list elements. `(product [1..4] == 24)`

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Creates a list with *n* copies of a value:
`(repeat 3 (0,0) == [(0,0),(0,0),(0,0)]`

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse a list. `(reverse [1..4] == [4,3,2,1])`

values.name: scanl
values.comment:
Reduce a list from the left, building up all of the intermediate results into a list.

      scanl (+) 0 [1,2,3,4] == [0,1,3,6,10]

values.name: scanl1
values.comment:
Same as scanl but it doesn't require a base case. List must be non-empty.

      scanl1 (+) [1,2,3,4] == [1,3,6,10]

values.name: split
values.comment:
Split a list with a given seperator.

      split "," "hello,there,friend" == ["hello", "there", "friend"]

values.name: sum
values.comment: Get the sum of the list elements. `(sum [1..4] == 10)`

values.name: tail
values.comment:
Extract the elements after the head of the list. List must be non-empty.
`(tail [1,2,3] == [2,3])`

values.name: take
values.comment: Take the first n members of a list: `(take 2 [1,2,3,4] == [1,2])`

values.name: unzip
values.comment: Decompose a list of tuples.

values.name: zip
values.comment:
Combine two lists, combining them into tuples pairwise.
If one list is longer, the extra elements are dropped.

      zip [1,2,3] [6,7] == [(1,6),(2,7)]
      zip == zipWith (,)

values.name: zipWith
values.comment:
Combine two lists, combining them with the given function.
If one list is longer, the extra elements are dropped.

      zipWith (+) [1,2,3] [1,2,3,4] == [2,4,6]

name: Maybe

datatypes.name: Maybe
datatypes.comment:
The Maybe datatype. Useful when a computation may or may not
    result in a value (e.g. logarithm is defined only for positive
    numbers).
datatypes.raw: data Maybe a = Just a | Nothing

values.name: cons
values.comment:
If `Just`, adds the value to the front of the list.
    If `Nothing`, list is unchanged.

values.name: isJust
values.comment: Check if constructed with `Just`.

values.name: isNothing
values.comment: Check if constructed with `Nothing`.

values.name: justs
values.comment: Filters out Nothings and extracts the remaining values.

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Apply a function to the contents of a `Maybe`.
    Return default when given `Nothing`.
values.raw: maybe : b -> (a -> b) -> Maybe a -> b

name: Mouse

values.name: clicks
values.comment: Always equal to unit. Event triggers on every mouse click.

values.name: isClicked
values.comment:
True immediately after the left mouse-button has been clicked,
and false otherwise.

values.name: isDown
values.comment:
The current state of the left mouse-button.
True when the button is down, and false otherwise.

values.name: position
values.comment: The current mouse position.

values.name: x
values.comment: The current x-coordinate of the mouse.

values.name: y
values.comment: The current y-coordinate of the mouse.

name: Prelude
document: Everything that is automatically imported

name: Random

values.name: float
values.comment:
Produces a new signal that changes whenever the input signal changes.
The new values are random numbers in [0..1).

values.name: range
values.comment:
Given a range from low to high and a signal of values, this produces
a new signal that changes whenever the input signal changes. The new
values are random number between 'low' and 'high' inclusive.
values.raw: range : Int -> Int -> Signal a -> Signal Int

name: Set

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Get the difference between the first set and the second. Keeps values
that do not appear in the second set.
values.raw: diff : Set comparable -> Set comparable -> Set comparable

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty set.

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Fold over the values in a set, in order from lowest to highest.
values.raw: foldl : (comparable -> b -> b) -> b -> Set comparable -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Fold over the values in a set, in order from highest to lowest.
values.raw: foldr : (comparable -> b -> b) -> b -> Set comparable -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert a list into a set, removing any duplicates.

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a value into a set.
values.raw: insert : comparable -> Set comparable -> Set comparable

values.name: intersect
values.comment: Get the intersection of two sets. Keeps values that appear in both sets.
values.raw: intersect : Set comparable -> Set comparable -> Set comparable

values.name: map
values.comment: Map a function onto a set, creating a new set with no duplicates.
values.raw: map : (comparable -> comparable') -> Set comparable -> Set comparable'

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a value is in a set.

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a value from a set. If the value is not found, no changes are made.
values.raw: remove : comparable -> Set comparable -> Set comparable

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a set with one value.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a set into a list.

values.name: union
values.comment: Get the union of two sets. Keep all values.
values.raw: union : Set comparable -> Set comparable -> Set comparable

name: Signal
document:
The library for general signal manipulation. Includes lift functions up to
`lift8` and infix lift operators `<~` and `~`, combinations, filters, and
past-dependence.

Signals are time-varying values. Lifted functions are reevaluated whenver any of
their input signals has an event. Signal events may be of the same value as the
previous value of the signal. Such signals are useful for timing and
past-dependence.

Some useful functions for working with time (e.g. setting FPS) and combining
signals and time (e.g.  delaying updates, getting timestamps) can be found in
the [`Time`](/docs/Signal/Time.elm) library.

# Combine
@docs constant, lift, lift2, merge, merges, combine

# Pretty Lift
@docs (<~), (~)

# Past-Dependence
@docs foldp, count, countIf

#Filters
@docs keepIf, dropIf, keepWhen, dropWhen, dropRepeats, sampleOn

# Do you even lift?
@docs lift3, lift4, lift5, lift6, lift7, lift8

datatypes.name: Signal
datatypes.raw: data Signal a = Signal

values.name: <~
values.comment:
An alias for `lift`. A prettier way to apply a function to the current value
of a signal.

values.name: combine
values.comment: Combine a list of signals into a signal of lists.

values.name: constant
values.comment: Create a constant signal that never changes.

values.name: count
values.comment: Count the number of events that have occured.

values.name: countIf
values.comment: Count the number of events that have occured that satisfy a given predicate.
values.raw: countIf : (a -> Bool) -> Signal a -> Signal Int

values.name: dropIf
values.comment:
Drop events that satisfy the given predicate. Elm does not allow undefined
signals, so a base case must be provided in case the predicate is never
satisfied.
values.raw: dropIf : (a -> Bool) -> a -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: dropRepeats
values.comment:
Drop sequential repeated values. For example, if a signal produces the
sequence `[1,1,2,2,1]`, it becomes `[1,2,1]` by dropping the values that are the
same as the previous value.

values.name: dropWhen
values.comment:
Drop events when the first signal is true. When the first signal becomes
false, the most recent value of the second signal will be propagated. Until the
first signal becomes true again, all events will be propagated. Elm does not
allow undefined signals, so a base case must be provided in case the first
signal is always true.
values.raw: dropWhen : Signal Bool -> a -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: foldp
values.comment:
Create a past-dependent signal. Each value given on the input signal will
be accumulated, producing a new output value.

For instance, `foldp (+) 0 (fps 40)` is the time the program has been running,
updated 40 times a second.
values.raw: foldp : (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Signal a -> Signal b

values.name: keepIf
values.comment:
Keep only events that satisfy the given predicate. Elm does not allow
undefined signals, so a base case must be provided in case the predicate is
never satisfied.
values.raw: keepIf : (a -> Bool) -> a -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: keepWhen
values.comment:
Keep events only when the first signal is true. When the first signal
becomes true, the most recent value of the second signal will be propagated.
Until the first signal becomes false again, all events will be propagated. Elm
does not allow undefined signals, so a base case must be provided in case the
first signal is never true.
values.raw: keepWhen : Signal Bool -> a -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: lift
values.comment: Transform a signal with a given function.
values.raw: lift  : (a -> b) -> Signal a -> Signal b

values.name: lift2
values.comment: Combine two signals with a given function.
values.raw: lift2 : (a -> b -> c) -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c

values.name: lift3
values.raw: lift3 : (a -> b -> c -> d) -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d

values.name: lift4
values.raw: lift4 : (a -> b -> c -> d -> e) -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d -> Signal e

values.name: lift5
values.raw: lift5 : (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f) -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d -> Signal e -> Signal f

values.name: lift6
values.raw:
lift6 : (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g)
      -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d -> Signal e -> Signal f -> Signal g

values.name: lift7
values.raw:
lift7 : (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> h)
      -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d -> Signal e -> Signal f -> Signal g -> Signal h

values.name: lift8
values.raw:
lift8 : (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> h -> i)
      -> Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal c -> Signal d -> Signal e -> Signal f -> Signal g -> Signal h -> Signal i

values.name: merge
values.comment:
Merge two signals into one, biased towards the first signal if both signals
update at the same time.
values.raw: merge : Signal a -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: merges
values.comment:
Merge many signals into one, biased towards the left-most signal if multiple
signals update simultaneously.

values.name: sampleOn
values.comment:
Sample from the second input every time an event occurs on the first input.
For example, `(sampleOn clicks (every second))` will give the approximate time
of the latest click.
values.raw: sampleOn : Signal a -> Signal b -> Signal b

values.comment:
Informally, an alias for `liftN`. Intersperse it between additional signal
arguments of the lifted function.

Formally, signal application. This takes two signals, holding a function and
a value. It applies the current function to the current value.

The following expressions are equivalent:

         scene <~ Window.dimensions ~ Mouse.position
         lift2 scene Window.dimensions Mouse.position
values.raw: (~) : Signal (a -> b) -> Signal a -> Signal b

name: Text

datatypes.name: Text
datatypes.raw: data Text = Text

values.name: asText
values.comment:
Convert anything to it's textual representation and make it displayable in
browser

        asText == text . monospace . show

Excellent for debugging.

values.name: bold
values.comment: Make a string bold.

values.name: centered
values.comment: Display centered, styled text.

values.name: color
values.comment: Set the color of a string.

values.name: header
values.comment: Make text big and noticable.

values.name: height
values.comment: Set the height of text in pixels.

values.name: italic
values.comment: Italicize a string.

values.name: justified
values.comment: Display justified, styled text.

values.name: link
values.comment: Create a link.

values.name: markdown
values.comment: for internal use only

values.name: monospace
values.comment: Switch to a monospace typeface. Good for code snippets.

values.name: overline
values.comment: Draw a line above a string.

values.name: plainText
values.comment: Display a plain string.

values.name: righted
values.comment: Display right justified, styled text.

values.name: strikeThrough
values.comment: Draw a line through a string.

values.name: text
values.comment: Display styled text.

values.name: toText
values.comment: Convert a string into text which can be styled and displayed.

values.name: typeface
values.comment:
Set the typeface of some text. The first argument should be a comma
separated listing of the desired typefaces

        "helvetica, arial, sans-serif"

Works the same as the CSS font-family property.

values.name: underline
values.comment: Underline a string.

name: Time

aliases.name: Time
aliases.comment:
Type alias to make it clearer when you are working with time values.
Using the `Time` constants instead of raw numbers is very highly recommended.

values.name: delay
values.comment:
Delay a signal by a certain amount of time. So `(delay second Mouse.clicks)`
will update one second later than any mouse click.
values.raw: delay : Time -> Signal a -> Signal a

values.name: every
values.comment:
Takes a time interval t. The resulting signal is the current time, updated
every t.

values.name: fps
values.comment:
Takes desired number of frames per second (fps). The resulting signal
gives a sequence of time deltas as quickly as possible until it reaches
the desired FPS. A time delta is the time between the last frame and the
current frame.

values.name: fpsWhen
values.comment:
Same as the fps function, but you can turn it on and off. Allows you
to do brief animations based on user input without major inefficiencies.
The first time delta after a pause is always zero, no matter how long
the pause was. This way summing the deltas will actually give the amount
of time that the output signal has been running.
values.raw: fpsWhen : number -> Signal Bool -> Signal Time

values.name: millisecond
values.comment:
Units of time, making it easier to specify things like a half-second
`(500 * milliseconds)` without remembering Elm’s underlying units of time.

values.name: since
values.comment:
Takes a time `t` and any signal. The resulting boolean signal is true for
time `t` after every event on the input signal. So ``(second `since`
Mouse.clicks)`` would result in a signal that is true for one second after
each mouse click and false otherwise.
values.raw: since : Time -> Signal a -> Signal Bool

values.name: timestamp
values.comment:
Add a timestamp to any signal. Timestamps increase monotonically. Each
timestamp is related to a specfic event, so `Mouse.x` and `Mouse.y` will always
have the same timestamp because they both rely on the same underlying event.

name: Touch

aliases.name: Touch
aliases.comment:
Every `Touch` has `xy` coordinates. It also has an identifier
`id` to distinguish one touch from another.

A touch also keeps info about the initial point and time of contact:
`x0`, `y0`, and `t0`. This helps compute more complicated gestures
like taps, drags, and swipes which need to know about timing or direction.
aliases.raw: type Touch = { x:Int, y:Int, id:Int, x0:Int, y0:Int, t0:Time }

values.name: taps
values.comment:
The last position that was tapped. Default value is `{x=0,y=0}`.
Updates whenever the user taps the screen.

values.name: touches
values.comment: A list of ongoing touches.

name: Transform2D
document:
A library for performing [2D matrix transformations](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformation_matrix#Affine_transformations).
It is used primarily with the `groupTransform` function from `Graphics.Collage` and
allows you to do things like rotation, scaling, translation, shearing, and reflection.

# Basic Transforms
@docs identity, matrix, rotation

# Multiplication
@docs multiply

datatypes.name: Transform2D
datatypes.raw: data Transform2D = Transform2D

values.name: identity
values.comment:
Create an identity transform. Transforming by the identity does
not change anything, but it can come in handy as a default or
base case.

          / 1 0 \\
          \\ 0 1 /

values.name: matrix
values.comment:
Creates a transformation matrix. This lets you create transforms
such as scales, shears, reflections, and translations.

      matrix a b c d dx dy

          / a b \\
          \\ c d /

And `dx` and `dy` are the translation values.
values.raw: matrix : Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Float -> Transform2D

values.name: multiply
values.comment:
Multiplies two transforms together:

      multiply a b

          / a11 a12 \\  .  / b11 b12 \\
          \\ a21 a22 /     \\ b21 b22 /

values.name: rotation
values.comment:
Creates a [rotation matrix](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation_matrix).
Given an angle t, it creates a counterclockwise rotation matrix:

          / cos t  -sin t \\
          \\ sin t   cos t /

name: WebSocket
document:
A library for low latency HTTP communication. See the HTTP library for
standard requests like GET, POST, etc. The API of this library is likely to
change to make it more flexible.

# Open a Connection
@docs connect

values.name: connect
values.comment:
Create a web-socket. The first argument is the URL of the desired
web-socket server. The input signal holds the outgoing messages,
and the resulting signal contains the incoming ones.
values.raw: connect : String -> Signal String -> Signal String

name: Window
document:
Provides information about the container that your Elm program lives in.
When you embed Elm in a `<div>` it gives the dimensions of the container, not
the whole window.

# Dimensions
@docs dimensions, width, height

values.name: dimensions
values.comment:
The current width and height of the window (i.e. the area viewable to the
user, not including scroll bars).

values.name: height
values.comment: The current height of the window.

values.name: width
values.comment: The current width of the window.

name: Graphics.Collage

aliases.name: Form
aliases.raw:
type Form = {
  theta : Float,
  scale : Float,
  x : Float,
  y : Float,
  alpha : Float,
  form : BasicForm
 }

aliases.name: LineStyle
aliases.comment:
All of the attributes of a line style. This lets you build up a line style
however you want. You can also update existing line styles with record updates.
aliases.raw:
type LineStyle = {
  color : Color,
  width : Float,
  cap   : LineCap,
  join  : LineJoin,
  dashing    : [Int],
  dashOffset : Int
 }

datatypes.name: BasicForm
datatypes.raw:
data BasicForm
  = FPath LineStyle Path
  | FShape (Either LineStyle FillStyle) Shape
  | FImage Int Int (Int,Int) String
  | FElement Element
  | FGroup Transform2D [Form]

datatypes.name: FillStyle
datatypes.raw:
data FillStyle
  = Solid Color
  | Texture String
  | Grad Gradient

datatypes.name: LineCap
datatypes.comment: The shape of the ends of a line.
datatypes.raw: data LineCap = Flat | Round | Padded

datatypes.name: LineJoin
datatypes.comment:
The shape of the “joints” of a line, where each line segment
meets. `Sharp` takes an argument to limit the length of the joint. This
defaults to 10.
datatypes.raw: data LineJoin = Smooth | Sharp Float | Clipped

values.name: alpha
values.comment: Set the alpha of a `Form`. The default is 1, and 0 is totally transparent.

values.name: circle
values.comment: A circle with a given radius.

values.name: collage
values.comment:
A collage is a collection of 2D forms. There are no strict positioning
relationships between forms, so you are free to do all kinds of 2D graphics.

values.name: dashed
values.comment: Create a dashed line style with a given color. Dashing equals `[8,4]`.

values.name: defaultLine
values.comment:
The default line style, which is solid black with flat caps and sharp joints.
You can use record updates to build the line style you
want. For example, to make a thicker line, you could say:

        { defaultLine | width <- 10 }

values.name: dotted
values.comment: Create a dotted line style with a given color. Dashing equals `[3,3]`.

values.name: filled
values.comment: Create a filled in shape.

values.name: gradient
values.comment: Fill a shape with a [gradient](/docs/Color.elm#linear).

values.name: group
values.comment:
Flatten many forms into a single `Form`. This lets you move and rotate them
as a single unit, making it possible to build small, modular components.

values.name: groupTransform
values.comment:
Flatten many forms into a single `Form` and then apply a matrix
transformation.

values.name: move
values.comment:
Move a form by the given amount. This is a relative translation so
`(move (10,10) form)` would move `form` ten pixels up and ten pixels to the
right.

values.name: moveX
values.comment:
Move a shape in the x direction. This is relative so `(moveX 10 form)` moves
`form` 10 pixels to the right.

values.name: moveY
values.comment:
Move a shape in the y direction. This is relative so `(moveY 10 form)` moves
`form` upwards by 10 pixels.

values.name: ngon
values.comment:
A regular polygon with N sides. The first argument specifies the number
of sides and the second is the radius. So to create a pentagon with radius
30 you would say:

        ngon 5 30

values.name: outlined
values.comment: Outline a shape with a given line style.

values.name: oval
values.comment: An oval with a given width and height.

values.name: path
values.comment: Create a path that follows a sequence of points.

values.name: polygon
values.comment:
Create an arbitrary polygon by specifying its corners in order.
`polygon` will automatically close all shapes, so the given list
of points does not need to start and end with the same position.

values.name: rect
values.comment: A rectangle with a given width and height.

values.name: rotate
values.comment:
Rotate a form by a given angle. Rotate takes standard Elm angles (radians)
and turns things counterclockwise. So to turn `form` 30° to the left
you would say, `(rotate (degrees 30) form)`.

values.name: scale
values.comment: Scale a form by a given factor. Scaling by 2 doubles the size.

values.name: segment
values.comment: Create a path along a given line segment.

values.name: solid
values.comment: Create a solid line style with a given color.

values.name: sprite
values.comment:
Create a sprite from a sprite sheet. It cuts out a rectangle
at a given position.

values.name: square
values.comment: A square with a given edge length.

values.name: textured
values.comment:
Create a textured shape. The texture is described by some url and is
tiled to fill the entire shape.

values.name: toForm
values.comment:
Turn any `Element` into a `Form`. This lets you use text, gifs, and video
in your collage. This means you can move, rotate, and scale
an `Element` however you want.

values.name: traced
values.comment: Trace a path with a given line style.

name: Graphics.Element

aliases.name: Element
aliases.raw: type Element = { props : Properties, element : ElementPrim }

aliases.name: Position
aliases.raw: type Position = { horizontal : Three, vertical : Three, x : Pos, y : Pos }

aliases.name: Properties
aliases.raw:
type Properties = {
  id      : Int,
  width   : Int,
  height  : Int,
  opacity : Float,
  color   : Maybe Color,
  href    : JSString,
  tag     : JSString,
  hover   : ()
 }

datatypes.name: Direction
datatypes.raw: data Direction = DUp | DDown | DLeft | DRight | DIn | DOut

datatypes.name: ElementPrim
datatypes.raw:
data ElementPrim
  = Image ImageStyle Int Int JSString
  | Container Position Element
  | Flow Direction [Element]
  | Spacer
  | Markdown
  | Custom

datatypes.name: ImageStyle
datatypes.raw: data ImageStyle = Plain | Fitted | Cropped (Int,Int) | Tiled

datatypes.name: Pos
datatypes.raw: data Pos = Absolute Int | Relative Float

datatypes.name: Three
datatypes.raw: data Three = P | Z | N

values.name: above
values.comment:
Stack elements vertically. To put `a` above `b` you would say:

        a `above` b

values.name: below
values.comment:
Stack elements vertically. To put `a` below `b` you would say:

        a `below` b

values.name: beside
values.comment: Put elements beside each other horizontally.

values.name: color
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given background color.

values.name: container
values.comment:
Put an element in a container. This lets you position the element really
easily, and there are tons of ways to set the `Position`.
To center `element` exactly in a 300-by-300 square you would say:

        container 300 300 middle element

By setting the color of the container, you can create borders.
values.raw: container : Int -> Int -> Position -> Element -> Element

values.name: croppedImage
values.comment:
Create a cropped image. Take a rectangle out of the picture starting
at the given top left coordinate. If you have a 140-by-140 image,
the following will cut a 100-by-100 square out of the middle of it.

        croppedImage (20,20) 100 100 "yogi.jpg"

values.name: fittedImage
values.comment:
Create a fitted image given a width, height, and image source.
This will crop the picture to best fill the given dimensions.

values.name: flow
values.comment:
Have a list of elements flow in a particular direction.
The `Direction` starts from the first element in the list.

        flow right [a,b,c]

          +---+---+---+
          | a | b | c |
          +---+---+---+

values.name: height
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given height.

values.name: heightOf
values.comment: Get the height of an Element

values.name: image
values.comment: Create an image given a width, height, and image source.

values.name: layers
values.comment:
Layer elements on top of each other, starting from the bottom.
`(layers == flow outward)`

values.name: link
values.comment: Create an `Element` that is a hyper-link.

values.name: opacity
values.comment:
Create an `Element` with a given opacity. Opacity is a number between 0 and 1
where 0 means totally clear.

values.name: size
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a new width and height.

values.name: sizeOf
values.comment: Get the width and height of an Element

values.name: spacer
values.comment:
Create an empty box. This is useful for getting your spacing right and
for making borders.

values.name: tag
values.comment:
Create an `Element` with a tag. This lets you link directly to it.
The element `(tag "all-about-badgers" thirdParagraph)` can be reached
with a link lik this: `/facts-about-animals.elm#all-about-badgers`

values.name: width
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given width.

values.name: widthOf
values.comment: Get the width of an Element

name: Graphics.Input
document:
This module is for creating standard input widgets such as buttons and
text boxes. In general, functions in this library return a signal representing
events from the user.

The simplest inputs are *one-way inputs*, meaning the user can update
them, but the programmer cannot. If you need to update an input from
within the program you want the slightly more complex *two-way inputs*.
This document will always show the one-way inputs first, *then* the
two-way inputs.

# Buttons
@docs button, customButton, buttons, customButtons

# Fields
@docs field, password, email, fields, FieldState, emptyFieldState

# Checkboxes
@docs checkbox, checkboxes

# Drop Downs
@docs stringDropDown, dropDown

# Mouse Hover
@docs hoverable, hoverables

aliases.name: FieldState
aliases.comment:
Represents the current state of a text field. The `string` represents the
characters filling the text field. The `selectionStart` and `selectionEnd`
values represent what the user has selected with their mouse or keyboard.
For example:

        { string="She sells sea shells", selectionStart=3, selectionEnd=0 }

This means the user highlighted the substring `"She"` backwards.

values.name: button
values.comment:
Create a button with a given label. The result is an `Element` and
a signal of units. This signal triggers whenever the button is pressed.

values.name: buttons
values.comment:
Create a group of buttons.

 * The first argument is the default value of the `events` signal.
 * The `events` signal represents all of the activity in this group
   of buttons.
 * The `button` function creates a button
   with the given name, like “Submit” or “Cancel”.
   The `a` value is sent to `events` whenever the button is pressed.
values.raw:
buttons : a -> { events : Signal a,
                 button : a -> String -> Element }

values.name: checkbox
values.comment:
Create a checkbox with a given start state. Unlike `button`, this
result is a *signal* of elements. That is because a checkbox has state
that updates based on user input. The boolean signal represents the
current state of the checkbox.

values.name: checkboxes
values.comment:
Create a group of checkboxes.

 * The first argument is the default value of the `events` signal.
 * The `events` signal represents all of the activity in this group
   of checkboxes.
 * The `checkbox` function creates a
   checkbox with a given state. The `(Bool -> a)` function is used
   when the checkbox is modified. It takes the new state and turns
   it into a value that can be sent to `events`. For example, this
   lets you add an ID to distinguish between checkboxes.
values.raw:
checkboxes : a -> { events : Signal a,
                    checkbox : (Bool -> a) -> Bool -> Element }

values.name: customButton
values.comment:
Create a button with custom states for up, hovering, and down
(given in that order). The result is an `Element` and  a signal of
units. This signal triggers whenever the button is pressed.

values.name: customButtons
values.comment:
Create a group of custom buttons.

 * The first argument is the default value of the `events` signal.
 * The `events` signal represents all of the activity in this group
   of custom buttons.
 * The `customButton` function creates a button with three different visual
   states, one for up, hovering, and down. The resulting button has dimensions
   large enough to fit all three possible `Elements`.
   The `a` value is sent to `events` whenever the button is pressed.
values.raw:
customButtons : a -> { events : Signal a,
                       customButton : a -> Element -> Element -> Element -> Element }

values.name: dropDown
values.comment:
Create a drop-down menu. When the user selects a string,
the current state of the drop-down is set to the associated
value. This lets you avoid manually mapping the string onto
functions and values.

values.name: email
values.comment:
Same as `field` but it adds an annotation that this field is for email
addresses. This is helpful for auto-complete and for mobile users who may
get a custom keyboard with an `@` and `.com` button.

values.name: emptyFieldState
values.comment:
The empty field state:

        { string="", selectionStart=0, selectionEnd=0 }

values.name: field
values.comment:
Create a field with the given default text. The output is an element
that updates to match the user input and a signal of strings representing
the content of the field.

values.name: fields
values.comment:
Create a group of text input fields.

 * The first argument is the default value of the `events` signal.
 * The `events` signal represents all of the activity in this group
   of text fields.
 * The `field` function creates a
   field with the given ghost text and initial field state.
   When the field is modified, the `(FieldState -> a)` function
   takes the new state and turns
   it into a value that can be sent to `events`. For example, this
   lets you add an ID to distinguish between input fields.
values.raw:
fields : a -> { events : Signal a,
                field : (FieldState -> a) -> String -> FieldState -> Element }

values.name: hoverable
values.comment: Detect when the mouse is hovering over a specifici `Element`.

values.name: hoverables
values.comment:
Detect when the mouse is hovering over some elements. This
allows you to create and destroy elements dynamically and still
detect hover information.
values.raw:
hoverables : a -> { events : Signal a,
                    hoverable : (Bool -> a) -> Element -> Element }

values.name: password
values.comment: Same as `field` but the UI element blocks out each characters.

values.name: stringDropDown
values.comment:
Create a drop-down menu for selecting strings. The resulting
signal of strings represents the string that is currently selected.

name: JavaScript.Experimental
document:
A pair of very experimental functions for converting between
Elm records and JavaScript objects. It currently uses a best effort
conversion that can cause runtime errors. This API should change and
improve as we find its key failings.

# Converting between Elm records and JS Objects
@docs toRecord, fromRecord

values.name: fromRecord
toRecord
